Difference-in-Differences

Author

Stephanus Steven Halimkesuma

1 Load the data

#| output: asis
hospdd <- readRDS(“E:/Master Study/TUHH/Wise 23-24/Causal Data Science for Business Analytics/Causal_Data_Science_Data/hospdd.rds”)

head(hospdd)

2 Use filter() to subset the data and mean() to calculate the mean of the subset

mean_satis_newpcd <- hospdd %>% filter(procedure == 1) %>% summarise(mean_value = mean(satis))

mean_satis_oldpcd <- hospdd %>% filter(procedure == 0) %>% summarise(mean_value = mean(satis))

3 Compare the result

print(“Mean of Hospital Satisfaction where new procedure is applied:”) print(mean_satis_newpcd) print(“Mean of Hospital Satisfaction where new procedure is NOT applied”) print(mean_satis_oldpcd)

4 Convert time variables to factors

hospdd\(month <- as.factor(hospdd\)month) hospdd\(hospital <- as.factor(hospdd\)hospital)

5 Perform difference-in-differences analysis using linear regression

6 Include group and time fixed effects

7 Option 1: Include as.factor(month) + as.factor(hospital)

model1 <- lm(satis ~ frequency * month + as.factor(month) + as.factor(hospital), data = hospdd)

8 Option 2: Include month + hospital

model2 <- lm(satis ~ frequency * month + month + hospital, data = hospdd)

9 Display the regression results

print(“Linear Regression Results (Option 1):”) summary(model1)

print(“Linear Regression Results (Option 2):”) summary(model2)
